items.text: In fiscal year 2025, our restaurant and beer garden showed significant revenue fluctuations. Beer garden revenue peaked at €60,000 in July, while restaurant revenue reached €45,000 in October. Customer numbers soared during the summer months, hitting 2,600 in July, which greatly boosted sales. However, December saw beer garden revenue plummet to €10,000. Personnel costs remained stable, peaking at €23,000 in September. Despite the successful summer, winter months highlighted areas needing attention. Moving forward, we'll implement strategies to maintain customer engagement year-round. Overall, the year was marked by strong seasonal performance, particularly in the summer.

- Revenues in the beer garden go up in summer due to season, people want to drink outside.

- Restaurant total revenue drops during summer season when beer garden rises.

- Number of customers higher in summer than winter due to good weather and increased free time activities.

- Personnel costs relatively consistent, peak in September.
Over the summertime there is less total revenue, although there are more customers. I am confused because for me total revenue would mean all the parts of the restaurant are included.

In the fiscal year 2025, revenues varied each month. Beer garden revenue peaked in June and July at €60,000, while restaurant revenue was highest in October at €45,000. Customer numbers rose to 2,600 in July but fell later in the year. Despite lower revenues in winter, summer months boosted total earnings significantly. Personnel costs remained mostly steady, between €18,000 and €20,000, with a peak of €23,000 in September. The year clearly showed seasonal trends, with summer being the strongest period. This variability suggests the need for strategies to improve off-season performance. Overall, the year emphasized the impact of seasonal demand on finances.

Beer garden revenue was especially high in the summer months. Therefore, the indoor restaurant revenue was lower. In the winter months, indoor restaurant revenue was higher than usual, but all in all, the revenue for the indoor restaurant was around 25.000 euros. In the summer months, there were more customers, therefore more personnel was hired (or at least the personnel costs were higher). Still, there were no losses in summer.

The beer garden revenue, as expected, rose during the warmer months, whilst the restaurant revenue decreased during said months, as most likely people preferred to eat outside if possible. The number of customers also rose during the warmer months (part of spring, summer, part of autumn). Personnel costs stayed relatively constant throughout the year, with June, September, and October showing a slight rise in costs.

In the fiscal year 2025, the revenues for both the beer garden and restaurant showcased notable fluctuations throughout the year. The beer garden revenue peaked in July, reaching an impressive €60,000, while the restaurant revenue hit its highest point in October at €45,000. This stability in restaurant earnings was crucial, especially during the winter months when revenues dipped. Customer numbers increased steadily, attaining a maximum of 2,600 in July before tapering off towards the end of the year. Personnel costs were variable, generally trending upward, with the highest costs recorded at €23,000 in September. The variations in revenue and customer counts highlighted the seasonal nature of the business. Overall, the summer months stood out as the most lucrative period for both the beer garden and restaurant. This contrast underscores the importance of strategic planning for off-peak seasons to maintain profitability.
Ich möchte mich gerade lieber auf die Vorlesung konzentrieren, sry. Die Zeit ist nicht mehr hierfür übrig.

In the fiscal year 2025, the restaurant and adjoining beer garden demonstrated significant revenue fluctuations. The beer garden revenue peaked in July at €60,000, reflecting the success of outdoor dining during the summer months. Conversely, restaurant revenue reached its highest point in October at €45,000, indicating a strong performance during the fall. The total number of customers saw steady growth, peaking at 2,600 in July before experiencing a slight decline in the later months. Personnel costs varied, hitting a peak of €23,000 in September, likely linked to increased customer volumes. Overall, seasonal trends indicated a robust summer business while the cooler months saw a decline in beer garden activity. This suggests potential for strategic marketing to promote the restaurant during off-peak times. Ultimately, the balance between managing costs and optimizing revenue was crucial throughout the year.

Revenues:
Total revenue increases up to october, after which revenue drops due to drecreases from the beer garden.

However, separate trends for revenue are visible from the beer garden and the restaurant revenues. Beer garden revenues appear to increase significantly (essentially double) starting april and decrease significantly (about third themselves) in november. This implies that the beer garden revenues increase much more during warmer months.

While the revenue trends for the restaurant appear to be more consistent and less prone to fluctuations from seasons, there is still a trend towards the winter months being more revenue-inducing as people decide to stay indoors.

Personnel costs have fluctuated around 19-20k euros per month, with increases appearing to match particularly revenue-intense months such as september and October, though a larger dataset is needed to verify this interpretation.

The number of customers steadily increase as the months pass, despite the reduction in revenues and personnel costs starting November.
